Aroma: Roast, vanilla, chocolate, coffee, cocoa Flavour: Barrel, cocoa, liqourice, roast, vanilla, bourbon, sweetness. Medium to full bodied. Rosty sweet and bourbondense end. Light alcohol on lips and palate.

Bottle #20 at Papsøs blindtasting.
Black coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of caramel and dark chocolate with notes of liquorice.
Sweet and roasted flavour of caramel, dark chocolate and liquorice with notes of hops and alcohol.
Roasted and warming alcoholic finish.

Bottle, blind #20. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma is dark malty and slight roasted. Sweet malty, boozy and caramelish. Subdued chocolate. Dark roasted malt. Bitter, dark malty and roasted finish. Lingering dark malty.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of wavers1. Pours pitch black with a creamy light brown head. Hard roasted malts and smooth Bourbon in the nose, but not overly sweet or hot. Solid body, sweet hard roasted malts and vanilla but again - not excessively sweet. Warming alcohol in the finish. Very balanced. 210810
Pours black, with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, bourbon, tobacco, chocolate, and alcohol. Flavor is bourbon, roasted malt, dark/bitter chocolate, alcohol, wood and coffee.  Smooth, heavy body.

Straight Black pour with a tiny tan head.  Aroma is creamy chocolate, some booze, roast and some light burnt notes as well. MMmm.. 
Mouthfeel is full and creamy.  Notes of roast chocolate and oaky booze fill my mouth.  also some dark roast and vanilla, toffee.  Amazing brew..

Bottle poured into a tulip glass produced a dark brown, almost black body with thick brown head.  Decent lacing down the glass.  Aroma of smoke and spice with some roastiness.  Flavors of roasted malts, smoke, pepper, oak, and tobacco leaf with a strong alcohol presence in the finish.

bottle shared with my dad TreborWhip, pours thick black, menacing brown head, good spotty lacing. Aroma is light barrel, heavy roast, some smoke.  Flavor is sweet, tobacco, black pepper, burnt malts, and a mild boozy finish.

2010 Bottle - Thanks inflatablehair!!! - Pours a thick and almost black with a medium sized tan head...aroma is plummy with cocoa, light soy, carob...flavour is similar, great chocolate presence, alcohol, vanilla and light caramel, old red fruit...not sure if my description accurate portrays how I felt, but this definitely exceeded expectations...really fing tasty~!

time for the bookends of death!! .. . Pours a black hole black .. lots of roasted cocoa and dark roast .. . very smooth and drinkable for 14% .. a very well made beer that really seems to have its ducks in a row .. a cllass act all the way .. . Dont juckopose anything in a macroscope in this universe.
Bottle courtesy of drowland at Proof tasting - 7/23/10.  Black pour.  Aroma of cocoa and oak.  Creamy, chocolate, warm, wood, cocoa, bourbon and vanilla.  Good balance.  Desert beer.

Bottle from BevMo - 

Aroma - the nose erupts with loads of dark chocolate, roasted malts, toffee, molasses with a strong oak/bourbon note.  

Appearance - black thick body, creamy light tan head, long lasting...perfect.

Taste - near perfect balance between sweet and bitter for an impy.  Caramel, scorched marshmallows, burnt wood/ashy, dark chocolate, bourbon and wood.  Neither base overpowers the other.  Really nice.

Palate - creamy, velvety smooth, long lingering finish

Overall - could not have picked a better beer for my 1800 rating here on RB.  Paired the 2nd half with some homemade brownies w/ Guittard chocolate chunks and it was quite exquisite.  Defintely a momentous beer.

Bottle  Pours a good black with a decent tan head.  The head lasts okay and laces fairly well.  Aroma is good, roast, alcohol, sweet fruit, and some cookie.  Has a good carbonation.  The flavor is good.  Has a nice alcohol burn.  The sweetness is real good.  Has a nice licorice ending.  Has a full body.  The texture is syrupy.  Has a real good finish and a wonderful aftertaste.  This is a real good beer.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2012 BCTC 2010, thanks to Rudolf. big black dark pour. boozy, chocolate, coffee, rich roasted malts. Full & lingering flavors. intense, very flavorful & very well made
rerate: quite possibly the best beer ive had. tap at Blue Monk

650 ml bomber from Bev4less. Thanks for holding this for me Freddy. Pours and opaque black color with a medium tan head that fades to 1/4 inch and holds. The nose is earthy dark roasted grains, burnt toast, raisins and some hot alcohol. The flavor is earthy and roasty with well roasted grains, whiskey, prunes and dark biter chocolates. The palate is full smooth and creamy with lively carbonation. Finishes long and dry. Overall: Very tasty brew. I loved it.

7/23/10.  Huge thanks to mkade8883 for this awesome brew in my Secret Santa box!!  Huge buttery, vanilla, and coconut aromas followed by obvious bourbon.  Love it.  The flavor doesnt deliver as much as I was hoping, but there is nice chocolate and coffee, buttery vanilla, a hint of coconut, and a nice warming feel.  Very good!
Chocolate. Vanilla. Roast. This is a dessert beer all the way. High quality. Very rich. Lovely.

22 oz. bottle shared by xmarcnolanx- thanks again, Mark!  Pours a super dark opaque brown, near black, with a small tan head that doesnt last long.  Aroma of bourbon, oak, chocolate, mocha, tobacco and a little vanilla.  Barrel notes lead the flavor- oak, bourbon, vanilla- along with notes of molasses, tobacco, leather, and ash.  The notes of the aroma are a lot more subtle than in the flavor.  The 13% ABV isnt overwhelming, though.  Full-bodied, with minimal carbonation and a thick, smooth, heavy mouthfeel.  Great imperial stout.

Pours pitch black.  Great cocoa and cigar notes in the aroma.  Flavor is like a liquid 90% cocoa chocolate bar with solid hop backing.  Super rich.  Less complex but more hedonistic than the anniversary series.

Aroma is chocolate, bourbon, oak, and some residual sweetness.
Taste is intensely bourbon, well carbonated, oak, chocolate, sweetness, hops, and more alcohol.  Definitely hot, but not overwhelmingly so.
Finish is sweet, slightly hot (bourbon), chocolate, and residual bitterness.
Solid.

2010-07-01. Black body with a nice brown head that fades. Rich flavour starts with rich dark malt, followed by a slow and steady bourbon invasion. Peaks with a good amount of bourbon in the middle, very mild wood accents, bourbon fades out graciously leaving a smaller amount to linger long into the finish. Moderate bitterness comes in waves, hints at buttery vanilla. Aroma is milder than expected, sweet dark malt, vanilla wood and mild bourbon. 7+ Very smooth full bodied palate is lightly carbonated. 4+ WOW. Richly flavoured, lightly warming it just brings everything together extremely well and is surprisingly drinkable for such a big beer. Excellent. Bottle at Seattle International Beer Festival

Bomber from the Co-Op in Davis, CA (but they have run out). Pours black with a decent tan head. Aroma is chocolate, dark chocolate over strong oak. Full bodied with foamy carbonation.  Flavor is burnt wood, caramel, baking chocolate, bitterness. Bourbon? Maybe. Vanilla? I think so. Is this complex? No sh.. This is really good sippin. Finishes smoothly burnt and pretty bitter. Heat? Amazing. Its hardly present. A really good drink.

bottle.  dark brown with a sizeable tan frothy head.   aroma of figs, sherry, dak chocolate.  nice tobacco, vanilla, and oak layer as well.  tasty tabacco, dark fruit, bourbon taste.    a bita throat warming booze.  soft. quaffable.  enjoyed drinking this quite a bit.  shared with my old man who was in town visiting.  he seemed to like it as well.   would drink again in a heart beat.  awesome beer.

bomer thanks to bleeng.  Shared at July Houston RB Tasting.  Pours black with a light-brown head.  Nose is of ash and coffee.  Taste is of ash, coffee and chocolate malt.  Mouthfeel is thick and chewy.  This was the top brew of our tasting, IMO, and we had several top-100 brews.  Had originally planned on trading my bottle, but may keep it now after tasting this,  Wow!

[3077-20100702] Sample. Dark fruity roast aroma has lots of wood and hints of banana. Brown black body with a quick foamy dark brown head. Flavour is like a creamy banana roast malt with light smoked wood and lots of wood afterward. Full body is very smooth. Great texture considering the alcohol it covers up.
(@ SIB 2010, Seattle, WA)
Black color/ light brown head. Mild aroma is dry wood, bourbon, earthy dark malts. medium bodied with soft co2. Mildly astringent tobacco flavor with dark malt, coffee, wet wood, bourbon, mineral.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: pitch black with dark tan head. strong bourbon and alcohol notes in the aroma. strong bourbon flavor and very smooth for the abv. nice vanilla finish with a oaky hint. amazing beer.

Pours jet black with a small tan head.  The scent is heavy with alcohol and chocolate, along with notes of bourbon and malts.  The taste is wonderful, heavy notes of bourbon and vanilla.  A great beer.

Bottle shared at the July Houston RB tasting-thank me! Color is dead black with a thick tan head. Nose is alcohol and chocolate-tons of aroma in this one. Taste has some subtle whiskey notes, chocolate, a bit hot but the alcohol seems to fit in with the flavors rather than distract from them.  Very thick like a milkshake and way too easy to drink. Dangerous and delectable. This is a supreme beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottle from bleeng.Pours a deep, thick onyx with an aroma of melted chocolate and coffee grounds after brewing a pot of joe.  (Not Tucker)  Flavor is chocolate malt ball candy soaked in wet coffee grounds and oaked bourbon chocolate syrup.  Thick, chewy mouthfeel.  Nice beer.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 19, 2012 Bottle. Poured black with a very thin dark brown head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma was full of sweet toasted chocolate and with undertones of sweet bourbon and roasted malt. Flavor had an interesting french toast with bananas and chocolate flavor that was delicious. I would go in to more depth about the specific notes but I keep coming back to that flavor profile. Overall very good beer.

Bottle This beer rocks! Pours pitch black with a small, creamy, well-tanned head. The aroma is a mélange of bourbon, oak, vanilla, red wine, mocha, blueberries and purple grapes. Full-bodied with a velvety mouthfeel and gentle, caressing carbonation. The flavor is a perfect marriage of bitter and burnt and sweet caramel, vanilla and milk chocolate. Bittersweet, chocolaty finish.  Thanks to darkguardian for sharing this bottle of world class beer!

Thanks to JW77 for sharing this one.  This is quite the "wow" beer.  Pours obsidian black with a dark head.  Nose is all manner of darkness: chocolate, roast, a bit of earth, more chocolate, some subtle wood and bourbon notes with bits of vanilla and hints of booze.  Flavor is exactly the same with a very thick mouthfeel.  An absolutely outstanding beer that I cannot help mourning the empty glass.

Big thanks to wavers1 for this bottle.  Pours pitch black with a small brown head.  Aroma  is chocolate, toffee, with a hint of booze.  Silky smooth on the tongue.  Flavor is sweet chocolate, caramel, toffee, some raisin, and a slight hoppy and pleasant alcohol burn in the finish.  Fuck yeah this is delicious!
Bottle sampled at SIB, pours black with a tan head. Aroma of deep roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Flavour follows, with molasses and sweetness. Excellent stout.

22oz. bottle.  Pours dark brown/black with a large fluffy tan head.  Aroma is milk chocolate, light and rich espresso, molasses, some ripe dark fruits, vanilla, oak, and light bourbon; wow lots going on, but gels well together.  Flavor is more chocolate, molasses, espresso, nice notes of bourbon, oak and vanilla, and a little more overripe dark fruits.  Very well put together from start to finish.

Bottle. Gk b party. Black. Thin tan head.  Light but complex aroma. Sweet.  Choc, molasses, coffee rich malt.  Smooth and easy. Nice. I can feel it in my plums.  Bring them to the farmers market.  Sell them two plums for the price of one.

Shenandoah Throwdown, 22oz bottle, thanks kmweaver.  Medium tan head atop black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, some smoke, alcohol, grapefruit.  Taste is moderately sweet, chocolate, smoke, some alcohol, grapefruit.  Smooth medium-full body.

When I first poured this beer, I thought it was flat. No real head and black. I tell my drinking buddy, " I hope this was worth the money"? First smell is coffee, a lot of coffee. Tastes of vanilla, bourbon and chocolate. The flavors blend to perfection. Not a question in my mind that this beer is worth the money. If anyone wants to do a trade, I am in...Because I will never see this beer in Florida.

22oz bottle. Pours a rich charcoal black. Nose is tobacco, dark chocolate, vanilla, bourbon. Complex. Its lacking something I cant quite put my finger on. I think its just a matter of needing a year in the bottle to make it all come together. Flavor is absolutely fantastic for a bourbon lover like me. Vanilla, smoke, leather and dark fruits meld with a hint of roasted malt and dark chocolate. Sweeter than the Hell and Damnation 666 I had earlier and lacking that beers exquisite balance, but still an amazing beer. This is so tasty and while its got a bit of heat, it doesnt even register as close to 13%. Another fantastic beer from Firestone Walker. Masterful barrel blending on this beer.

Bottle shared by footbalm, thank man 
Appearance: Poured black with a small tan head with some lacing left on the sides of the glass, nice legs that stick to the glass 
Aroma: Roasted malts, oak, bourbon and chocolate 
Taste: Smooth mouthfeel of chocolate, vanilla with a slightly bitter finish 
Very nice Imperial stout. The alcohol is very well hidden.

Bomber thanks to Eric! Pours a totally black color with a medium beige head. The aroma is huge licorice, charcoal, fruity dark malts. The flavor is initially just a load of sweet candies, especially licorice, chewy, very hot, bitter chocolate and perhaps some metallic hops fight to the fore, not much bourbon. Very enjoyable. It mellowed as I drank it and was less sweet, more rich oil can.

Big imperial stout.  Piny hops on the aroma with notes of roast, chocolate, and coffee.  Very sweet and chocolaty.  Slighty creamy with bitter finish and tons of alcohol.  Too overpowering to be enjoyable.

Pours almost black with a creamy brown head that dissipates to a thin layer in less than a minute. The aroma is chocolate, nuts, bourbon, vanilla, wood, prunes, dates, raisins etc... The flavor is extremely hot and boozy with lots of charred wood, chocolate and raisins. It goes down a lot like straight bourbon. Huge alcohol burn and very bitter. Hooo daddy! The bourbon barrel aging is nicely integrated and its not too sweet. On the down side, put me in the camp that thinks this needs at least another year or two in the bottle to settle down a bit.

Wow! Pours black with a tan head. Some loss of retention. Nose is light bourbon, oak, velvet smooth melted chocolate and hint of licorice. Taste is out of this world smooth. Very full mouth. Melted Chocolate, light licorice. hint of ultra smooth no burn bourbon, oak and other subtleties. World class beer.

22 oz. bottle from Jimbowood. A very thick, very black beer with a nice tan head. The aroma is charred, chocolate, tar, bourbon, vanilla. The taste is sweet, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, toffee, wood and crackerish. Its very creamy on the palate and the bourbon flavors are their but more subdued compared to other BBA beers leaving this one a little more balanced and not a bourbon bomb. And is layered with flavors and has a nice charred chocolate taste with a low amount of carbonation. Keep in mind this is a very sweet beer and its sweetness starts to show up more as you finish your glass or 22oz. bomber. A barrel aged beer for the barrel aged lover.

My Bottom Line:
This rich dessert of an Imperial Stout extends blackberry esters, bourbon, dark chocolate and raisins onto one of the smoothest and wealthiest bodies found in the style.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sheet of foam crowns the brown-edged blackness. 
-Apart from the woods contribution, the nose doesnt have that much to offer.
-The contemplative finish incorporates wooden barrel notes to an alcohol splash, perfect to cut through the amazingly oily mouthfeel. 
-This may not be one of the most complex Imperial Stouts out there, but it achieves its goal magnificently. 

On tap at the brewery tasting room.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2012 Bomber. Aroma is an intoxicating blend of mocha, vanilla, roasted malt and bourbon. Appearance is charcoal black with a thin milky layer of light brown head. Excellent lacing throughout the glass. Taste starts off with big and bold roasted malt and dark chocolate flavors followed by creamy caramel, vanilla, espresso and black cherries. An oaky bourbon flavor is also present in each sip. Mouthfeel is silky, creamy and slightly syrupy with low carbonation. It finishes sweet and roasty with a pleasantly warm alcohol finish. The barrel aging process definitely enhances the rich chocolate and caramel malt flavors. The oak and bourbon flavors also add additional layers of complexity. It would pair quite well with a rich and creamy chocolate dessert. This is an exceptional Imperial Stout that would taste sublime after being aged for a few years.

22oz bottle from Bottle Barn, $12.99 I believe, and no date--maybe a little over a month ago?  Black body with a couple finger tan head, fair retention.  Lots of chocolate and bourbony vanilla in the nose, followed by some light butter cream and oatmeal.  Theres also some solid underlying roast.  Flavor is pretty hot with lots of bourbon., added juicy raisins, still has the butter cream notes and whatnot.  Finishes semi-dry with bitterness at a 4, fairly boozy but very tasty.  Light to moderate carbonation with a thick full body.  Just a good tasty hot bourbonated imperial stout.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: On tap at Papago for all of 5 minutes.  Pours pitch black with a brown ring of foam.  Smells of soy sauce and molasses.  Approximates Bells 9000.  Tastes of Colgate, black licorice, toasted marshmallow, and dark fruits on the mid.  Finishes with bourbon and vanilla that really linger on the palate.  Alcohol becomes more apparent as this one warms.  It should age like a champ.  Well done.

Ive had this several times at the Bistro Barrel Aged festivals, just never rated it.  This is from a 22 ounce bottle purchased at the Davis Food Co-OP.  The aroma on this is really nice.  Lots of chocolate, with moderate sweetness and a nice deal of bourbon and some oaky-wood hints, too.  There also is some leather present and a little bit of salty soy sauce, too.  Really quaffable.  Opaque black body with a medium light brown head that is strong and leaves some stellar lacing.    Starts a little acidic and hot on the tongue, before some chocolate maltiness and roastiness comes through.  Strong bourbon in the middle with some oak, too.  The finish has a bit of an astringency present, and a fairly nice bitterness.  The finish is rather warming...this definitely has some alcohol in it, but the ethanol isnt overly noticeable.  The astringency is a bit weird, but otherwise this is enjoyable.  I dont know if aging this will really improve it much, though.

Bottle from KnB. Pours black as night, with a beautiful 1-finger of brown sugar-colored head. Aroma is blanketed in oatmeal, almost a chocolate-chip oatmeal cookie. The first sip is absolutely heavenly. Full, creamy mouthfeel with just the perfect  little amount of carbonation is accompanied by silky smooth flavors of roasty oak, oatmeal and hints of chocolate, coffee and bourbon. Whereas so many of these newer BB-aged RIS are just bourbon bombs, this is a wonderful display of restraint and subtlety. Long afterfinish leaves me wanting more.

Bottle shared by ewestern
A wonderful imperial stout that successfully throws in a perfect mix of bourbon flavor.  Probably the best bourbon barrel aged beer Ive ever had, just because it adds to the beer without masking any of the other great stout characteristics.  Also one of the few beers that I can actually taste tobacco in.  A well made stout that is strong in flavor but smooth and drinkable.  Nice one.
Bottle purchased at Bev 4 Less. Nice aroma of coffee, charred wood, some chocolate on the nose. Flavors of toasted malts, chocolate, coffee and wood. Really good.

Good God this beer is fucking amazing! From the moment you pour this black stallion into your glass youll notice its alluring aroma of chocolate, vanilla, oak, licorice, and bourbon. Upon tasting this full bodied beast, youll notice that as you practically chew the beer, the tastes of chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, and oak transport you to a magical land... Well maybe thats the 13% abv... but it goes down SMOOTH and is just absolutely fucking delicious. I only wish that I could get more of these.
UPDATED: APR 28, 2014 Bottle shared with bigmmartin & ericwestern.  Aroma is bourbon, oak, burnt malts, and chocolate.  Smooth/complex palate.  Leaves a nice roasted malts/bourbon aftertaste.

On tap at Beachwood BBQ.  

Chocolate, vanilla, some oak, and a nice amount of bourbon.  Not in your face bourbon, but enough to add to the complexity.  Smooth considering the high ABV.  Mmmmmmmmmmmmmm!
Got this at the Monterey Deli in San Francisco. Pours like motor oil. Tastes like smokey chocolate, vanilla, and coffee, finishes with lots of alcohol. Amazing imperial stout.

Back -N- Black  Brouwers Café  Seattle Beer Week 2010
Aroma  Dark malt roasty with tons of chocolate and coffee in the nose. 
Appearance  Dark Black in color, Clear with a thin head.   
Flavor  Thick rich flavors with that hint of tobacco along with bitter chocolate.  Lots of spices. As this warmed up.  
Palate    Dry Thick finish with a Nice Mouthfeel. 
Overall  Big ole Impy Stout flavor with tons of flavors.

Big thanks to rhertan for sharing this one.

Pours pitch black out of the bottle with light mahogany around the edges.  There is a small creamy tan head that recedes quickly to a thin collar and leaves no lacing but some sticky legs along the sides.

The aroma is fantastic dark chocolate, coffee, lots of dark fruits including raisins and plums.  There is also some tobacco, spicy oak and vanilla beans.

The taste is wonderful as well.  There is plenty of dark chocolate and tobacco.  Also lots of dark fruits, vanilla and caramel.  The finish leaves a slight alcohol burn though nothing to indicate the 13% abv.

Super smooth mouthfeel, full bodied with soft carbonation.  Spicy oak and tobacco in the finish.

Decadent, complex, outstanding.  Theres so much going on in this one and it all comes together in one fairly drinkable package.

tap at Rose and Crown in My 2010. Pours with a dark brown almost black color,  brownish thin head. Aromas of bourbon and chocolate and leather. Flavors exhibit mainly bourbon and alcohol not much else. Mouthfeel is good, finish has some hoppy bitterness. This is an alcohol bomb that is overrated.

Creamy and rich without overdoing it. Boxed and foil sealed bomber pours pitch black with a deep chocolate mouse head. Toasty aromas of bourbon, walnut, and cocoa. For as rich as it tastes, this brew hits a nice balance between sweet maltiness and a touch of bitterness. Theres bourbon, but its in no way overwhelming. Overall, a real depth of flavors, then a real alcohol kick to the head at the end. Hope I can cellar a couple of bottles of this one.

On tap at Papago on 5-6-10.  Pours crude oil black with a thin brown head.  The nose is soy, dark chocolate, coffee and booze.  The taste is wood, tobacco, cocoa, dark fruits and spiked black coffee in the finish.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel.  Very good.

22, capped and foiled. Pours black with a dense and creamy burnt tan head--surging and pillowy, in fact; quite striking. Good webby lace all over the sides of the glass on the way down. Big chocolatey nose with some cherry cavendish tobbaco hanging around. Creamy medium body, soft carb. Mid-palate shows chocolate, cherry cordials, vanilla, bourbon, and some heat (but not much). Somewhat twangy finish.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2011 re-rate 17Jan2011:
Shared a bottle at Tustin Brewing w/ Barb, Vac & zug4abby

gorgeous chocolate and vanilla aroma, silky/creamy mouthfeel, great flavor
------- to Greg for sharing this beer. Its a nice looking black pour with a tan head. The flavor is of bittersweet chocolate with some dark cherries. The bourbon aging is nicely done; its very complementary; the beer isnt overshadowed by the bourbon barrel. Its a very enjoyable beer.

pours a midnight black with a small brown head, and great lacing.

smell is of nuts, bakers chocolate, licorice, some sour malt, and hops.

taste is thick, cocoa, nuts, and some sour malt, ends dry and nicely bitter.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2010 wow, this one is good. pours black with a genrous chocolate maltshake head, appears on a swirl, nice spotting and lacing. aroma is great, a lot of heat though, but very nice, a tone of oak, bourbon, chocolate and marshmallows. the taste is straight smores, 90% cacoa with charred, flaming marshmallows roasted over sappy oak. yum!  there is a ton of cocoa, and i keep getting marshmallow. the last thing this is is over barreled, imho.

On draft at release night at Taps in Petaluma, CA after the Hop Press guys went home I guess. Opaque and very dark with small persistent beige head. Aroma dominated by chocolate with dark fruit and bourbon. These folllow in succession in the flavor, which finishes glowingly warm without astringency.
Huge beer, symmetrical and classic. I guess since the style is so big, somehow a bodybuilding metaphor comes to me: Imperial Stout is the  Mr. Olympia contest of beer, and this is the Frank Zane of the style - perfectly proportional and yet compact in stature. Sure there are bigger guys (Dark Lord is the Segio Olivia, but I digress, and take the muscle lore too far) but this beer surpasses the requisites on all counts. I wonder what a year of aging would do to this one.

22 oz. bottle from Bevmo - Pours a dark brown color with a small tan head.  Faint spotty lacing.  Aroma is lightly roasted malt and oak/bourbon.  Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, and oak/bourbon.  Very nice.  Alcohol is noticeable, but doesnt seem like 13%.  Finish is fairly smooth with no unpleasant lingering aftertaste.  Medium to full body.  A very good beer.

On tap at the Brouwers stout fest 2010. Pours a glossy black, with a medium tan head. The nose is like a chocolate bar. Some brown sugar, some molasses - crazy sweet. The flavor follows suit. Theres some fruit as well - just a hint of overripe tropical fruit - but *tons* of chocolate. This is *velvety* smooth for 13%. Thick, maybe a bit hot. Great, great stuff. SO glad I got to try it on tap.

Nice oily black pour with a rich brownish head.  Aroma is insanely awesome.  Marshmallow, chocolate, light roast, oak, bourbon, molasses, raisins and some faint coffee tones and oh yeah...pipe tobacco.  Flavor is even better.  Perfectly rich chocolate flavors, bourbon, molasses, roasted marshmallows, coffee, roasted malt, ash, raisins....man this is really a superbly crafted beer.  Bravo.

Thanks Kevin for sharing this!

A- Body is big, thick, opaque and black. Pours with a soapy light brown head, which fades quickly, to a thin collar and leaves behind little lacing in the glass.

S- Nose is all about the bourbon barrel. Very woody, quite boozy, with a mild cocoa and bourbon sweetness.

T- Upfront is a big dose of roasted chocolate malt-which isnt present in the nose really at all and a pleasant surprise in the flavor. There is also a lot of oak and some bourbon. The alcohol becomes prominent for the finish in both flavor and heat.

P- Body is fairly heavy with a moderate weight and a lot of astringent alcohol consistency.

O- This brew, much like the full sail BBL stout, showcases the aspects of the barrel rather than the stout itself. Nothing wrong with that-but I prefer more balance. Its a decent, above average brew overall.

Serving type: bottle

22oz boxed bottle. Proprieters Reserve Series #1.
Pours as deep black/brown as any beer Ive seen. A dark tan head grows when poured and slowly reatreats into itself. The nose is dark chocolate, bourbon whiskey, vanilla, charred oak, hops, and alcohol. The taste is initially roasted coffee, vanilla, bourbon, and dark chocolate and transitions into a light hop presence, and more chocolate, and smoke. The palate is thick and chewy (not as much as Goose Island Bourbon County Stout) . The lacing is moderate and decently carbonated. The alcohol (13%) is well hidden. One of the best RISs Ive had. As good as Goose Island, Great Divide Oak Aged, and The Abyss.

Bottle thanks to visionaries (BA)!Near black with a thin tan ring for a head, lightly oily. Nose is washed out, mainly wood and ethanol with very little of the bourbon. Also light plum and anise. Flavor isnt as bad, the large, creamy body probably helping this, but its still dominated by wood and ethanol, some bourbon showing in a bit of light vanilla. There is also some chocolate and bitterness from roasted malt emerging in the finish. This continues to grow with warmth, chocolate taking control near the end of the glass. Despite this last cry of life, Parabola is a great example of barrel excess.

City Beer Store, Parabola release party. Two incredible barrel-aged beers from Firestone Walker in one night. Parabola pours a wall-to-wall black with a great brown head, thick and creamy. The aroma is complex and wonderful. Bourbon and oak are probably the strongest notes, but they dont dominate quite as much as in Parabola. Theres a ton of dark chocolate, a healthy dose of roasted malt and a touch of vanilla. Brown sugar, molasses and caramel round it out. The flavor is all barrel-aged imperial stout goodness. All of those roasty sugars did their magic in the barrel, changing and blending with the barrel notes. Its not exactly sweet, but there are plenty of sugars present. Theres definitely no unpleasant cloying sensation, despite its viscous feel. The finish gives a mild hop bite. This is a wonderful imperial stout.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2011 Thanks to Mr. Chopin for sharing this one.

A-pours jet black liquied with a nice mocha colored head that is quite dense

S-the nose is quite big, nice dark chocolate up front, notes of smoke. the wood kicks in, hint of vanilla with a good bit of booze in the back.

T-the taste is quite nicely balanced. lots of roasted malts and dark chocolate. the oak comes in behind and shows signs of vanilla. hints of alcohol in the back.

M-the body is huge, thick, soft and and velvety. carbonation holds the body, a little chalky in the feel with a good bitey finish.

D-this is a nice imperial stout with some good balance between the roasted malts and the barrel aging. not hugely complex and a little boozy but not bad.

On tap @ Papago & from the bottle...tap was a bit hotter.  Thin dense latte foam floats on a mahogany/onyx body that doesnt let a sliver of light pass through.  Aroma is cocoa, molasses, dark fruit, oak, ash, and bourbon/grain alcohol.  Flavor shows the harsh ABV more as it warms but also delivers vanilla, dark chocolate, barrel, roasted coffee, and tobacco.  Silky smooth and velvety texture.  Another winner by an amazing brewery!

Appearance:  Pours a midnight brown with a thin tan cap of froth. This beer is very viscous and leaves behind decent legs.

Aroma:  Dark chocolate, raisin, bourbon, huge oak, burnt roast,black cherry.

Taste:  A mixture of dark chocolate and bourbon right away, and as I taste in most bourbon barrel imperials, graham cracker and vanilla. As I dive in deeper, I get very pronounced wood notes, sharp burnt roast finishing with black coffee and spicy hop bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Like thick silky pudding or mousse. The booze gives it a very warm coating mouthfeel.

Overall: Another amazing big beer from Firestone Walker.  The hype on this was modest, and believe it or not, the price tag is spot on. This is nothing you would want to rush into.  I thought with it being a blend of former batches of Parabola, this would be less spicy and warm than it was.

On tap at Stones Oakquinox 2010.  Pours black with a very thin head.  Aroma of grainy roasted malts and barrel.  Flavor of very rich dark chocolate with notes of bourbon and tobacco.  More lovely dark chocolate in the finish with some light booziness (the 13% starting to show through).  Quite good stuff on tap, but I would love to get my hands on a bottle to rate.  (105, 298)

Impressive thick head of brown foam over jet black beer.  Thick chocoloate, coffee, and sweets in the aroma.  Excellent heavy stout flavor backed up by strong ABV.  Near barley wine flavors.  Seems a touch too sweet right now and I wonder if a year of storage may improve the beer even more.  Definitely worth a buy and its going fast (only ten cases remaining at the brewery as of 5 11 10).

On tap @ Papago (for about 5 minutes). Pour is black, head was..... well I didnt get a chance to see because I was late and thankfully someone was nice enough to save me a glass. Aroma is chocolate, molasses, cigar tobacco, vanilla and bourbon.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of plum, oak, trace amounts of smokey ash and a marshmallow from time to time.  Overall body was big and slick with a nice lasting finish.  Alcohol is very nicely integrated. I really like the tobacco depth of this imp, and can honestly say its one of the best that Ive had in a while.  I will definately be squirreling away a few bottles for myself, I suggest you do the same.
On tap at papago pours a. Deep black with a small brown head. Aroma is dark malts roast oak bourbon alcohol cocoa. Flavor is bourbon tannins oak chocolate roast. Bitter bourbon finish. Good stuff.

Tap @ Stone Oakquinox.  Pours black with almost zero head and light carbonation.  Bittersweet cocoa with some bourbon and vanilla notes, a little underwhelmed by this brew, will try the bottle and re rate.
On tap at Oakquinox..dark dark brown, almost black with a thin ring head...aroma is bourbon and alcohol..flavor is dark chocolate and bourbon..so tasty!

On tap at the brewery. Black with a thick, dense tan head. Aroma-bourbon and wood mostly, with underlying sweet vegetal notes. Taste- sweet, roasted malts, bourbon. Finishes well rounded and lingering bitterness. Alcohol well hidden.
Rating #700. Draft. Black pour with brown lacing head.  Huge chocolate roasty notes and bourbon notes from aging. Wow super drinkable with 13% and just a light warming.

Now this is a beer that stands up to the barrel. Incredibly heavy bourbon flavors balance by a HUGE malty imperial/roasted stout backbone.  So many whiskey/bourbon barrel beers are over powered by the wood & whiskey -- but my goodness does the Parabola ever buck that trend. Sampled at GABF and SF beer week.

A: Dark as night and wonderful viscosity to it. No head and no visible carbonation.

S: Vanilla, chocolate, licorice, some graham cracker, and slight booze.

T: A truly amazing beer. Very smooth vanilla flavor from the barrel, lots of chocolate, and some graham cracker. The booze is very well hidden in this monster, as well.

M: Huge body, velvety smooth.

D: I was expecting this one to be really overwhelming, but it wasnt at all. A fantastic beer, one that I wish I could have more often, and I actually ended up buying two glasses of it today.

On tap at Stone Bistro Firestone Night.  Pours a dark black with tan head.  Sweet roasted malt, oak, bourbon, chocolate, plum, vanilla, smoke, and some peat moss.  Nice creamy mouthfeel.  Excellent Stout.

Sample at GABF 2009. Pours a dark brown to black with tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of chocolate, smoke, molasses, ripe dark fruits, light bourbon, vanilla, and wood. Flavor is about the same. Medium to full body with a pleasing malty and bourbon finish. Well done.

Had a bunch of this at GABF.  All in all, its a pretty kick-ass imperial stout.  Pitch black and viscous with no head to speak of.  Aroma is roast, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, and wood.  Not too much bourbon.  Flavor is intense, awesome, and fairly sweet, with roasted malt, coffee, rich chocolate cake, hints of dark fruit, bourbon, oak, and vanilla.  Nicely balanced.  Mouthfeel is smooth, slick, and viscous with low carbonation.  Overall this is, as I would have said 10 years ago in my awkward youth, "the bomb diggity."

Sampled at GABF.  Got the last pour of this one from the keg.  Looks like I lucked out a bit.  Pours plack and oily, stains the glass.  Aroma of oak, bourbon, chocolate and roast.  Flavor is very roasty, with strong, dominant bourbon.  Lesser chocolate and vanilla flavors scuttle about.  Big and heavy, yet slick on the palate.  This is a bad ass Imp. Stout.  Would try again if I ever got the chance.

sample from the pitcher at GABF on 9/26/09...  pitch black pour with no head... slight bourbon nose... medium body with more bourbon notes over the mouth... very well balanced between the barrel aging and the roasted malt character.  very nice BA Imperial Stout...

Had this brew at GABF on 9/24/09.  Color is black with mellow carbonation and a small tight tan head.  Aroma is deeply roasted with a sweet note and oak.  This is a big rich brew with nice oak flavors, vanilla and a rich roasted taste.  After taste is dry with the roasted flavors hanging on.  Overall its a nice Imperial Stout.

GABF2009 - reminds me very much of FW10 and 11 - tons of toasted oak and coconut notes - however, where those beers were smooth and warming, this rough, and the alcohol simply burns - there is also a lot of charred wood character, which combines with some bitter black malt in ways I didnt find entirely pleasant - thick and heavy in the mouth - lacks balance - there are things about it that are quite tasty, but its just a little too much.

From the Jug at the GABF Colorado Convention Center, Denver 09/10/2008
Bourbon aroma. Beige head. Black strong in alcohol fruity and hoppy with a crisp dry and bitter coffee roast finish.

Had this on tap at the 2nd anniv. of Baileys Taproom in Portland, OR.  Colour... black with a thin maduro edge around the rim. Nose... toffee, bourbon, dark sweet chocolate and coffee. Palate... not much carbonation but viscous, heady, boozy, sweet-dark chocolate, cold coffee, treacle and a looooong, smooth finish with hints of lust, greed and treachery (in a good way!).

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2010 A big-ass RIS -- that I hyped considerably -- poured into a snifter at Blue Palms.  Aroma was quite woody, with peat, dark chocolate and noticeable booze.  Flavor had strong bourbon components, to go along with musty wood, licorice, soft roasts and firm booziness.  Finish is very warming, with vanilla-sweetness.  Palate is syrupy-thick throughout, verging on oily.  And it lasts a long, long time in your mouth.  There is much complexity here, but I think Firestone may have overdone this one.  The sweet-booziness is quite high, overriding other (perhaps more interesting) flavors. Or am I just over the mystique of the barrel-aged? 3.8.
update, 2010 bottling:  sampled 6/25/10: aged only a couple months.  Pours pitch black, viscous, dark brown wispy head.  Aroma is vanilla, oak, hint of chocolate and cigar, espresso.  Mouthfeel is extremely creamy and full, slides across your tongue like liquid marshmellow.  Flavor begins with almond-vanilla (barrel), bourbon, brown sugar.  This is soon layered with creamy chocolate and more malt.  The 80 IBUs is positively buried underneath all that malt!  Finish is long, warming. Obviously a great beer, though to me doesnt quite reach the intensity of flavors  or any one shining note, for that matter  that I find in world-class RIS.  Ill be happy to age a couple of these. 4.0.

I preface this with the fact that bourbon/whiskey beers are not my favorite.  The bourbon smell is clear and upfront.  Not much head on this but it is a well balanced beer.  It does not go to the spirits side.  Bit of a sugary aftertaste.

On tap at Blue Palms. Black body, thick and glass coating. No head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, oatmeal. Taste is nearly fruity up front with dates and plums, dark chocolate decadent brownie, and bourbon cake. Vanilla and lightly toasted coconut. Super thick mouthfeel, rich. Light carbonation. Reminds me a lot of Firestone Walker 12 (which is a good thing)!

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2010 Tap @ AnniBrew 2 Barrel Aged Beer Festival...  Poured black with no head.  Aroma was hot with alcohol and bourbon.  Thick, syrupy palate.  Coffee and chocolate flavors with roasted malts, earthy hops and a bourbon finish.

On tap.  Dark brown, borderline opaque black 

colored body with a thin head of creamy tan.  A fudgey, 

caramelly malt aroma is softened by some pleasing notes 

of vanilla and bourbon.  The barrel character is 

prominent, but integrated well into the beer and 

maintains a soft, rounded profile.  Notes of chocolate, 

but light on the roast.  Full bodied, softly carbonated 

mouthfeel with a rich, silky texture.  Sweet malt 

flavors of chocolate fudge, treacle, and vanilla flood 

the palate with a tasty dessert-like treat.  It kindly 

refrains from contributing any unpleasant cloying 

qualities.  Light on the roast qualities, with a dark, 

riesen candy flavor contributing the majority of the 

malt profile.  Some roasted prunes.  As in the nose, 

the barrel qualities are strong, but weave nicely into 

the malt characters.

Draft. A pitch black beer with a thin brown head. The aroma has notes of sweet malt, alcohol, roasted malt, fruits, prunes, and chocolate. The flavor is powerful with notes of prunes, over ripe fruits, alcohol, roasted malt, and chocolate, leading to adry roasted finish, where the alcohol tickles the tongue.
Poured @ NHC pro brewer night. Pours black. Nose is wood, some vanilla, BOOZE, bourbon, some cocoa. Flavor is chocolately, boozey, dark fruits, vanilla, wood and earthiness. Great offering.

6/18/09 on draft at the nhc. Aroma is highly alcoholic and very woody. Appearance is dark, dark brown with a low tan head. Flavor is toasty, highly sour, with moderate sweetness and dark fruit. Mouthfeel is full bodied with slight astringency and almost no carb texture. Overall, quite complex with sourness that makes it tough too have very much.

9 oz draft courtesy of the TB Hop Juice release (Warrenville, IL). Pours a pitch black opaque pour, a little brown around the edges, thick, good brown head that laces well. Aromas are a nice bourbon goodness, oak and vailla mixing with light booziness, roasted malts, coffee, some chocolate. There is a lot in there. Body is decent, not too thick, possibly a little thin. Bourbon comes through a little less full, roasted malts and smokey ash, a motuh coater with vanilla and caramel, coffee and some good vibes. The flavors are good, but could be more pronounced. Boozy and bourbon sticks to the palate for sure. Pretty damn good overall, but not the best of the genre. Cheers!

Draught at The Blue Palms.   Black with a small tan head.   Smooth deeply roasted malt and bourbon aroma.   The flavor is an integrated blend of dark chocolate cake, caramel, vanilla, and light bourbon.   The wood shows lightly but the overall barrel character is very integrated into the whole presentation of the beer, and the heat from the bourbon doesnt approach the richness of the malt.   Thick with a silky texture.   Probably the best bourbon-aged stout that Ive had.   The aging adds lots of complexity without drowning out the base beer.   Firestone Walker needs to quite wasting all of this in the anniversary blends and bottle it as a separate release.

sampled at 2008 FOBAB... poured black with reddish brown endges.  thin tan head and decent lacing on the glass... aroma of chocolate and caramel malt, a little woody but could have used a little more bourbon... sweet chocolate flavors with light roastiness and a moderate bourbon component.  lingering sweetness is a little off.  would like a larger sample of this in the future...

Very boozy, bourbon quality, this beer is warm and almost more barleywine like.  At %14, this is a bomb, and the alcohol overcomes.  Notes of chocolate, coffee, but really sweet, caramelly, and estery from the heat.  Traces of vanilla, toast and dried fruits underneath all of this somewhere. Lay these in a cellar for a few years and try, theyll probably be amazing.

yep, it’s an imppy, so it is black with a dark head. booze vanilla and chocolate with a strong roast presence. . hwew, this is hot. rummy cocoa. interesting, a slow sipper for sure  nice and thick, a great motuthfeel, but this is one that is just a touch too boozey. good flavors underneath the stomping foot of alcohol, chocolate cookie, vanilla, sweet caramel and a nice coffee bitter.
4 8 6 2 13

Had this at the Chicago Wood and Barrel Aged beer festival. Dark pour to be expected with a fast dying thin head.Not as smooth as some of the better stouts and alcohol is present and not very well hidden. I was a little let down by this as I am a big fan of the Walker brews.Noticeable oak and chocolate malts and a little bourbon coming through. A good brew but not great.

FOBAB 08’.  Poured black with a tan head.  Aroma was smooth chocolate, vanilla and caramel.  Taste was much the same with a nice balancing bitterness and some burnt coffee.  This one didn’t separate itself from some of the other great stouts I had that day, but it was still very good.

Portland Holiday Ale Fest 2008. Black body with a soft beige head. The alcohol kinda took over this beer, boozy throughout, and seemed to need more time to settle. Big chocolate nose, heavy with a strong bourbon buttery finish. Hints of cherry and dark chocolate long into the finish. The palate was very smooth, but the excess alcohol kept it a bit sharp. Once the alcohol settles this beer will be amazing, now it is just good.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2008 Pours deep brown with a thick pancake colored head. Full nose of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, vanilla, bourbon. The flavor was quite the same with quite a bit of heat thrown in for good measure. Creamy mouthfeel and lasting oak finish.
FoBAB 08.  Pour lkack with a brown head  The aroma is light toast with plenty of chocolate and fruit.  Well balanced bourbon, oak, and chocolate.  Oily and sweet.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2010 Resampled on draft at TAPS Petaluma during their release party. Much smoother and far less coffee-tinged / burnt bitterness than the batch I remember. Possible much improved. Are we allowed to say that on Ratebeer? 7.5.8.4.14=3.8

Draft @ Bistro BA Fest.  Pours a very dense, chocolate-brown color; light tan head with excellent retention and mixed-bubbled lacing; great, foamy pour.  Solid amounts of bitter chocolate, burnt coffee, and charred malts in the aroma; a touch hollow in the middle.  Full, dense mouthfeel: loads of bitter coffee grounds, intensely dense bitter chocolate; heavily roasted and burnt and mouthcoating; a touch overly heavy and viscous throughout; tons of coffee.  Lengthy finish: dark chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts out the wazoo; nothing close to delicate. 7.5.6.3.12=3.3
2008 Bistro Barrel Aged Fest.  Dark brown, smooth, creamy, chocolate, malty, dark fruits, little oats, little boubon, little wood.
Draft at the XII release in Paso Robles. Extremely dark pour, chocolate head. Great chocolatly aroma. This tasted like heaven, rick dark fruits and malts, just extraordinary. Wish this was bottled.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: GABF 08.  A beast of a beer...but not overdone.  The lush mouthfeel make this stand out . . . all the epic flavors you would imagine from a 10 month barrel stint.  I’m a sucker for these....

UPDATED: APR 17, 2010 Draft at EBF 07.  Pours a dark brown body with a tan head.  Bourbon oatmeal with chocolate and notes of dark fruit.  A bit creamy and enjoyable but not worth another sample.  Good brew. 3.7
Draft at SD.  Pours a black body whit a tan head.  Dark chewy chocolate tones, dutch chocolate.  Sweet and malty with some vanilla and coco notes.  a modest warming creamy with vanilla and dark fruit.  Really nice. 4.1
tried this beer at both the real ale festival and at beachwood bbq last night.....sooo fucking good...great interplay of bourbon and roasted malt flavors.....wish there was more

GABF 2007.  Oily in the glass without much head at all, just tracings of foam on top.  Oily roasty smell with hop oils and a little bit of malt sweetness apparent.  Nicely sweet in the mouth with the roast emerging late and only on the sides of the mouth, the sweetness is like confectioner’s sugar, slightly vanilla.  The finish starts with the roastiness in the malts, then the hops emerge and make it chewy, ultimately settling into an acrid bitter burn that was a bit off.  The hops are more apparent in this than other impy stouts I’ve had, which makes it nicely unique.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2011 Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is opaque black (flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately to heavily malty (chocolate, caramel, nuts, roasted grain), with notes of alcohol, vanilla, whiskey, wood, sherry.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Full body, creamy/syrupy texture, soft carbonation, heavily alcoholic.

Pleasant but somewhat ordinary aroma thats bursting with alcohol.  Combination of bitterness and alcohol keep the massive sweetness from being too oppressive. Too boozy for its own good, but if you can get past that its reasonably elegant underneath.

On draft at O’Brien’s for the CBC/WBC.

Appearance is a dense and dark brown hue, thick brown pillowy head, thick lacing on the glass.

Smell is a delicious and complex range of aromas: bourbon whiskey, oak, vanilla, cherries, chocolate and coffee malts, sweet milk, brown sugar/molasses.

Taste is initially smooth milk chocolate malts that transition quickly to boozy whiskey and wood, tones of vanilla and dark fruits, opens up to grainy oatmeal malts, finishes sweet and dry.

Mouthfeel is full-bodied, creamy smooth texture is very pleasing and well-crafted, moderate carbonation.

Drinkability is high, delicious and well-balanced barrel-aged stout, great malt profile and creamy texture, good oak presence that accents without dominating, sweetness fluctuates between milk chocolate and dark fruits, absolutely a wonderful beer and a must-try for any beer fan!
A tatsy treat on tap at CityBeer.  Lots of flavors in this one.  Bourbon and chocolate at the forefront with sublime fruit, vanilla and oak.  Good stuff from Firestone Walker.

Aged in Bourbon and served at Bailey’s Taproom 1 Year Anniversary--Poured a deep dark black-brown with a frothy thin beige head.  Complex nose and floavor profile of vanilla, dark fruits, raisins, toffee, brown sugar, molasses, bitter chocolate and bourbon oak.  Delicious!

Draft.  Dark Lord Day 2008.  Pitch black color.  Integrated aromas of dark chocolate, dark fruit, vanilla, bourbon and coconut.  Flavor is amazingly complex, with similar notes in the flavor as in the aroma.  This one really shows Firestone Walkers great barrel aging ability and gave Oak Aged Dark Lord a run for its money.

On cask at PP Real Ale Festival. Pours dark brown black with a thin, creamy, light brown head. Smells of bourbon, wood and sweet and sour maltiness. Tastes malty sour, slight vanilla and bourbon flavors. Full body, good carbonation.

On cask, sampled at the Real Ale Festival at Pizza Port Carlsbad on 6/13. My first sampler of the afternoon. Served on cask, super rich and creamy. Black color with a frothy maroon head and thick legs that coat the glass edges. Picture-perfect appearance. Huge bourbon nose with oak wood, syrupy molasses and vanilla extract. The flavor is packed with a huge oak barrel character, bourbon, leather, roasted malt, brown sugar oatmeal and a barbecue smoke tone. Extremely viscous, milkshake body. Very warming alcohol finish that knocks you in the head. Almost over the top, but damn tasty.

Tasted at the REal Ale fest.  Black with a creamy brown head.  Sweet milk chocolate aroma.  Mildly bitter chocolate taste, syrupy palate, robust coffee flavors, slight grain, and bourbon tastes evident.
Sample at DLD.  Dark color.  Smell of chocolate, bourbon, vanilla and malt.  Tastes the same.  Nice balance of the chocolate and bourbon.

Second guest beer sampled on draught at Dark Lord Days 2008. Pours an opaque and very dark brown brew with a thin tan head that quickly dissipates clean with just barely a swirly film top. Aroma of toasted and nearly burnt dark malt, a touch of chocolate, bourbon, vanilla and a touch of molasses. Taste is thick and chewy, full bodied, no carbonation with flavors of toasted dark malt, bourbon, chocolate and some vanilla. Finish continued the bourbon flavor with a finishing toasted dark malt that sticks around after the finish. Most excellent!

Draft @ DLD 08:  Pitch black pour with a cream head.  Big dark malt and bourbon nose with a bit of chocolate added.  This seemed a bit on the overwhelming bourbon side yet was still a treat in and of itself.  Full bodied and full of chocolatey bourbon goodness.  Very good.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2008 This was a gem a thick roasty IPS and best of all on tap at DLD,poured a thick dark and had no head ,the bourbon was not overwhelming but as the beer warm it was apparent,over this was a fantastic beer and very enjoyable.CHEERS!
The best tap brew I was able to get my hands on at DLD. Bourbon laced fresh chocolate cake aroma, big roasty chocolate ,bourbon taste with a chewy texture. Acknowledged as great by all who tasted it

On tap at Dark Lord Day 08.  Pours pitch black with a tan head.  Smells like alchohol and bourbon with a tail of roasted malts.  Has a heavy mouthfeel.  Has mostly bourbon taste with some malt aftertaste.  Very intense and very good brew.
UPDATED: APR 28, 2008 Draft at DLD. This had a ton of body and girth. Huge bourbon character. Deep colored head. Nice and sweet with a dessert feel. Not hot at all, really. Very tasty.

tap at dld 08.  Black,  tan head.  Aroma is buttered popcorn. Flavor is black jelly bean,  bourbon, mollases,  coffee,  diacytal,  a bit of hops round it out.  Strong boozy finish,  little carbonation

Draught at the 6th Boulder Strong Ale Festival.  Pours opaque with an average, frothy, dark brown head, somewhat diminishing with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (molasses, coffee), average hops (perfume), average yeast (leather) with notes of heavy alcohol and prunes.  Full bodied, alcoholic texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration,  moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

On tap.  Poured a thick, deep brown color with a moderate, deep tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, light coffee, vanilla, caramel, and bourbon.  Flavor consisted  of chocolate, roasted malts, caramel, vanilla, and a light spicy bourbon with a hint of alcohol on the finish, but I never would have guess 14%.  Full and smooth on the palate.  Definitely one of the highlights of the day.

On tap @ Boulder Strong Ale Fest poured a clear dark brown nearly black with a small lasting brown head. Aromas of bourbon, oak, chocolate, roastiness and light vanilla. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth. Flavors of bourbon, oak, vanilla, chocolate and light roastiness with a smooth lingering lightly sweet finish.A truly great and drinkable Imperial Stout!
On tap at Toronado. This black ale poured with a decent tan head. There is a huge chocolate malt flavor wth a nice warm alcohol finish.
I would have it again... but the first go was not impressive.  Especially given the Firestone beers I have enjoyed.  This one was a bit off-tasting, like old coffee and rather shallow.

Nose of boubon filled dark chocolate truffles with some mild chipotle pepper and vanilla. Full and rich with a very clean yet complex mouthfeel, notes oc cocoa laden dark fruit with some mild tobacco notes. Rich and full finish with no astringency.

Extreme Beer Fest 2/15/08:  I thought this was a very complex beer.  Initial taste was of a stout, with notes of smoke, roast, bitterness.  Then the bourbon started to kick in, followed by a sweet chocolate finish.  I thought the bourbon complemented this beer very well.

EBF NOTB.  Black pour with light brown head.  Strong bourbon, roasted malt, and chalky chocolate in the aroma.  The flavor is the same, but the alcohol seemed well hidden.  The palate was a little thin.

Sampled at the Night of the Barrels.  Poured black with a light brown head.   Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, wood and bourbon.  Flavor was a little disapoinintg.  A litte chalky in the favor.  Alcohol was well hidden.  A little disappointing overall.

sampled on tap at the San Diego Strong Ale Festival Nov 2008, an event shared with what seemed liked hundreds of ratebeerians and enjoyed mostly through a straw, since my face was a bloody mess of scabs and stitches. Solid black beer with a white head. malty aroma with hints of cofee an chocolate. flavor was strong with bitter choclate and cofee and some woods notes. finish strong with lots of alchol warming.

2007 PP SAF.  Deep black in color with a nice off white fluffy head. Deep caramel malty aroma. Vanilla, bourbon oak notes. Chocolatety notes. Chocolatety caramel toffee flavor. Sweet tasting. Finish is chocolatety.  Full bodied. Well balanced. Great.

Sampled at the PP SAF.  Lots of bourbon and wood on the aroma of this Black beer.  Coffee aromas made it through as well.  Flavors were more wood and bitter dark chocolate.  Nice creamy finish with a lot of alcohol warming.  Pretty darn good.
2007 PP SAF. Black black color. Aroma of bourbon, chocolate, and black licorice? Flavor is pretty similar. Noticeable alcohol.
On tap at PP Strong Ale Festival.  Creamy dark tan head.  Pitch black color.  Smells great with lots of chocolate. Full flavor of the same.  Mmmmmmm good.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 Rerate, 9th Beer of the Beer Spot Tasting Sunday March 30th, 2008.  Growler from TheKegergator, poured me a way to big snifter of this big beer.  Pours black with a light brown ring.  Nose is big and malty and nose is sweet.  Taste is sweet and chocolaty and very very nice.  

PP Strong Ale Fest 07.  Probably the first pour off the keg when it finally arrived.  Pours black with a 2 finger light brown head.  Nose is malty chocolate and coffee.  The taste is full of coffee, chocolate, sweet, big and very potent.
Nose was creamy w/ silky notes of vanilla and bourbon.  Beautiful creamy bourbon and vanilla flavors as well...nice silky thick & creamy mouthfeel.  Absolutely killer at that alcohol level.  Killer!
A bit of butter in the nose once you get past the vanilla/bourbon. Lots of fresh fruits including cherry and chocolate. You cant really taste too much of the 13%

On tap at the 2007 GABF: Pours an oily opaque with a nice, dense, frothy light brown head.  Aroma of sweet, rich dark chocolate, caramel, dates and oaky bourbon complexity.  Body is viscous and sweet with creamy dark chocolate and mild brown sugar flavors balanced with a lot of good bourbon character and some warmth toward an otherwise smooth finish.  A real nice beer and one of my favorites at the fest.

Tasted on tap at the 2007 Bistro West Coast Barrel Aged Beer Festival. This Imperial Stout pours a dark black color. Medium to large sized tan head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee, lots of bourbon and oak. A medium to full bodied Russian Imperial Stout. The malts are chocolate and coffee. The hops are earthy. Lots of flavors in this beer, chocolate, coffee, bourbon, oak, brown sugar and vanilla all combine and then seem to explode in your mouth. The 14% alcohol is noticeable but it not too bad. Nice roasty malt finish. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

On draft at the Bistros BA Fest 07.  Murky brown pour with very active carbonation and a  tan head.  Sharp bourbon aroma with sweet, sugary notes.  Somewhat thin mouth feel.  Bourbon and oak flavors.  Sweet and malty and pretty hot.
On tap at FoBAB 07.  Dark black/brown, syrupy, no head.  Roasted malt aroma with slight borubon.  Bourbon flavor with  dark fruit and roasted malt.  Medium to full body and creamy.  Nice.

(on tap @ the ba bistro fest)black body with a nice thick dark brown head.i grabbed marshmellows,chocolate,bourbon,and vanilla in the aroma.the flavor was much f the same.although the bourbon was a bit heavy,for some reason it didnt bother me in this beer.

On tap at the FoBAB 2007.  Pours dark brown with no head.  Aroma is sugary, vanilla, fruity and chocolaty.  Sugary bourbon and fruit with the roasted chocolate flavors with a little oak.  Decent but overshadowed by so many great beers.

On tap at FoBAB 5.  Poured black with darker brown highlights and a creamy deep brown head.  The aroma picked up sweet bourbon (and perhaps some brandy) sugars with dark chocolate beneath (the bourbon stuck out more).. vanilla and toasted oak rounded it out.  The flavor had deep, rich dark chocolate and bourbon sugars with tart oak and some alcohol warmth especially around the finish.. bit of molasses and some brown sugar added sweet malty complexity.. sweet finish with a kick and a nice oaky tartness.  Medium-ish bodied, and perhaps a touch lighter than it would have been due to the barrel aging.. nice and warm.  Good one!

FoBAB 2007.  Pours a darkish brown to black with a little ring of a tan head.  Subtle nose (Relatively).  Oaky sweet malt.  Vanilla and some bourbon soaked chocolate.  Small roast.  Substantial body.  Not watery or syrupy with low carbonation.  Big alcohol!!  Theres a balance of alcoholic bourbon with vanilla, some chocolate, but mostly straight oaky alcoholic bourbon.  The roast comes on late.  This is a sipper.  Not too cloying.  Lingering tannins some roast, a dry booze finish.
on tap at FoBAB V: pours black with no head. nose of coffee, dark chocolate. flavor of soy, chocolate, and nutty. not much bourbon here. no heat. decent stuff.
(Draught)  Pours dark brown body with a thick beige head.  Aroma of oak, sweet raisins, vanilla, and chocolate.  Flavor of oak, bourbon, dark chocolate, roasted malt, and nuts.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2012 
Date: October 11, 2007
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewfest, GABF
Appearance: black, frothy beige head
Aroma: sweet rum raison and dark chocolate aroma with dark chocolate enhanced by vanilla and oak for balance
Flavor: hot dark chocolate flavor, bourbon and vanilla for sweetness, lasting bitterness mixed with oak

Date: November 30, 2007
Mode: draft
Source: strong ale fest
Score: 4.0 to 4.3
Body: creamy body
Flavor: little alcohol in the flavor allows the rich chocolate and fruity character more soom to shine

Date: June 03, 2012
Mode: bottle
Words: first sunday
I love bourbon, rich chocolate, sweet caramel, hot alcohol in the finish, 

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 9/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 18/20
Rating: 4.3/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **** /4

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 Sampled @ GABF 2007.  Best beer @ the festival IMHO, and the best beer Ive rated.  Pours black w/ a small head w/ good retention.  Alcohol, vanilla, chocolate, bourbon, and coconut w/ a long after taste.  A light mouthfeel.  Very drinkable.  Similar to Dark Lord, but much more complex.
Sampled at the FOBAB.  Pours dark black with a thin head.  Heavy bitter roasts and chocolate notes blend very well with the Bourbon notes.  ABV is well hidden.

FoBAB 06: The beer pours mostly opaque with a small frothy ring. The aroma has a surprising note of lactic sour milk and a strange saison like floral quality. Oh, there was some of the standard chocolate, roast, and oat character expected but it was hard to discover it.  Lucky I did not find the sourness in the flavor but more towards bittersweet chocolate,  cashew, rye bread and grandma homemade oatmeal. The ending was a bit boozy but I found a hint of smoky malt and wood along with a dose of  Crème Brûlée burnt sugar. I dug this more I drank it. A strange brew but overall its taste out-weighted the nose.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2010 Rating #1 Tap at the Bistros 1st Annual Barrel Aged Festival 11-11-2006 (8 3 8 4 16).  Black color.  A vanilla aroma with chocolate malts.  A big bitter bite with a lot of intensity.  Rating #2 Bottle of the Reserve Series No. 001 in 2010 (8 3 8 4 18).  Black with a thin dark brown head.  A rich vanilla aroma with a robust chocolate, wood and roasted malt flavors.  The alcohol is warming but not too intense and the bourbon barrels add character without being overwhelming.

#913On tap at the 4th anual Festival of Wood and barrel Aged Beer festival at GI Wriglyville Nov 4th, 2006.This was one of the last ones that I had at the festival and was pretty blitzed by then. My notes say the following: Thin. Below average as compared to others but mmm good. 747414.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2014 Draft at The Bistro?s BA Beer Fest 11/11/06; Nose of bourbon, hops, semi sweet chocolate notes, and alcohol; rusty brown with a small tan head; flavor is chocolate, with fruitiness and some hops and and an alcohol finish. 7/4/7/3/13 3.54/16/10 at Firestone, Paso Robles. Nose of chocolate, a coffee note, light vanilla, and charred oak. Black as a moonless night with a medium, glass lacing, cinnamon tan head. Flavor is light bitterness, lots of chocolate, a keggy toasted oak. 8/5/8/4/16 4.1Draft at Imbibe Wine 5/26/12 Nose is chocolate, coffee, plenty of vanilla, and woody oak.. Black with a medium cinnamon head. Flavor is chocolate, vanilla, and lots of oak with a light bitterness. 8/4/9/4/17 4.2 2014 14% ABV version Nose is light oak, tobacco, bourbon, and coffee. Black with a small cinnamon tan head with only a tiny puff of gas released on opening. Flavor is tobacco, bourbon, and vanilla that finishes with moderate alcohol. I will have to try this one next to an original 12.5% bottle which is my favorite. 8/4/9/4/17 4.2

sampled at barrel-aged brewfest.  super hoppy.  cant-miss bourbon.  alcohol pretty obvious.  id say hop-dominated and smokiness in flavor.  bitter.  lighter-bodied.  taste some off-tastes.  not the best but not bad at all.

Mostly opaque and chestnut brown in color with some amber accents at the edges. An icy tan head mostly covers the top. Aroma reeks of lactic milk chocolate and gritty brownies. Black currant elicits an acidic shine while discretionary blueberry coffee grinds are aided by minty dark chocolate. Its somewhat at a loss for beneficials. Cool and harshly unsweetened chocolate rings prominently dry. Milk duds hit extremely hot on the palate with dark chocolate slabs converging on brownie mix while the cake batter elicits fewer moments of appreciation. The hotness is almost revolting and is mutinously destructive, especially when looked at from the scorched brownie crumb point of view.

This poured a black body with a slight tan head.  The Bourbon dominated nose and taste as if theyd left some liquor in the barrel before adding the ale.  Dark, sweet chcococalte covered caramel and hints of vanilla, oak, and a light nutty bitterness were also present but were getting beat up by the Bourbon and the alcohol.  This one was a bit over the top for my tastes.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve of Barrel Aged Beers, Chicago, IL 11/04/2006<font size=-1>

GABF 2006:  Opaque black with a brown head.  Great aroma of vanilla and chocolate.  The aroma had some sweetness but not too much of that or the bourbon.  Nice balanced amount.  The flavor was sweet and roasty.  Some more chocolate but not as much as the aroma.  Bourbon and vanilla but again a nice balance.  Pretty warming but not much alcohol in the taste.  I am sure the bourbon aspect helps hide it.

Called Rarabola. Draft. Black beer with a rich brown head. Oak, bourbon, and malt in the aroma. Big bourbon flavor with chocolate, slight oatmeal flavor with a vanilla cherry fruitiness. Slight alcohol presence (13% is hidden). Lingering bourbon and oak. Rich smooth body.

Cask sample at the 06 Real Ale Fest.  Alcohol, chocolate, rum in teh aroma.  Foamy tan head.  The flavo ris a bit high in fusel alcohols but otherwise has enjoyable rum, hersheys syrup, stron gcaramel malt.  Finishes with dry chocolate bean and sweet caramel malt and alcohol.
Cask at real ale fest. Jet black with a nice rcih thick foamey head, vanilla sweet chocolate. It ends with a crisp coffee flavor

On cask at PP Real Ale Festival 2006.  Pours a dark black color with a pretty nice looking (about a finger) sized tan head with a decent amount of lasting lacing.  Aroma is delicious with strong bourbon, roasted nuts and malt presence.  Flavor is even more delicious than the aroma with strong bourbon (slightly warming, but no over-powering), malts, roastiness and coffee through-out.  Big beer on the palate, but maintains a good balance with the warmth of the beer and the flavors.

(On cask at the PP Real Ale Fest 2006) This brew pours with a black body topped by a medium thick, brown head with a little lacing left on the glass.  The aroma is sweet and malty with nice vanilla and chocolate notes and a hint of coffee.  The flavor is full of Bourbon notes with hints of vanilla and nice malty chocolate undertones.  Full bodied and warming.

WOW! I dont know if i was drunk or if this brew is for real. But i will definitly grant it first place on my list until i can sample it again someday. From what i remember, It was silky smooth with a nose of vanilla and coffe. It reminded me very much of the Alesmith Speedway Stout, except it had less coffee and some more complexity to it. Vanilla, Anis, hops, raisins, Lots of coffee and a dense rich body. Nice slightly sweet roasted finish.
